title-group.article-title: Low Hemoglobin Concentration Is Associated With Poor Outcome After Peripheral Arterial Surgery

article-meta.aff: 1Liverpool Vascular and Endovascular Service, University Hospital Aintree, Liverpool, United Kingdom

author-notes.corresp: F. Torella, Liverpool Vascular and Endovascular Service, University Hospital Aintree, Longmoor Lane, Liverpool L9 7AL, United Kingdom. Email: f.torella@liverpool.ac.uk

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To assess the influence of low hemoglobin (Hb) concentration on major adverse cardiac events (MACE) and mortality in patients undergoing peripheral arterial surgery.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: This was a retrospective cohort study of patients undergoing peripheral arterial reconstructive surgery at a tertiary vascular center. Preoperative factors linked with the occurrence of MACE and death on univariate analysis (P ≤ .1) were included in a multivariate model to confirm the independent association with the outcome variables.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: A total of 360 consecutive patients (238 men) with a mean (standard deviation) age of 69 (10.7) years and Hb of 13.0 (2.12) g/dL treated under the care of a single specialist between January 2004 and December 2011 were included in the analysis. Of these, 193 (53.6%) were anemic. In all, 26 (7%) had a postoperative MACE and 18 (5%) died. On multivariate analysis, age > 80 years (odds ratio [OR] = 3; 95% confidence interval [CI] [1.2-7.5]; P = .025), renal impairment (OR = 3.2; 95% CI [.99-10.2]; P = .053), coronary disease (OR = 3.6; 95% CI [1.5-8.7]; P = .005), and low Hb (OR for each 1 g/dL drop below the mean = 1.4 [1.13-1.7]; P = .002) were independent risk factors for MACE. Unplanned surgery (OR = 4.5; 95% CI [1.2-16.9]; P = .025) and low Hb (OR for each 1 g/dL drop below the mean = 1.5; 95% CI [1.14-1.86]; P = .002) were independent risk factors for death.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: In peripheral arterial surgery, preoperative low Hb is associated with MACE and death. Further investigation is necessary to elucidate whether this relationship is causal. Meanwhile, consideration should be given to treating preoperative anemia as a significant risk factor for adverse outcome in this setting.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Anemia is commonly encountered before major surgery and is an independent risk factor for poor outcome. 1–3 Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) are prone to anemia of chronic disease. This is likely a consequence of repeated infection and the inflammatory response associated with critical limb ischemia, 4 while iron-deficiency anemia may reflect poor nutrition in others.

The relationship between anemia and postoperative outcome is well documented in patients undergoing major cardiac, orthopedic, and gastrointestinal surgery 5–8 ; however, there is a paucity of published data specifically addressing the influence of low hemoglobin (Hb) on clinical outcome in patients undergoing peripheral arterial surgery (PAS). Most patients undergoing PAS have PAD and are thus prone to perioperative cardiac events due to the high prevalence of coronary atherosclerosis. 9 Furthermore it has been demonstrated that anemia may worsen prognosis after such events. 10 The aim of this study was to quantify the impact, if any, of preoperative Hb concentration on the incidence of major adverse coronary events (MACE) and mortality in patients undergoing PAS.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This was a retrospective cohort study on consecutive patients undergoing peripheral arterial reconstructive surgery between January 2004 and December 2011. Patients scheduled for surgery in order to treat either occlusive or aneurysmal disease were eligible for inclusion. Exclusion criteria were emergency surgery (<12 hours from admission to hospital), nonreconstructive procedures (ie embolectomy), amputation, surgery for aortoiliac aneurysms, surgery to create vascular access, endovascular procedures, and surgery for trauma. All procedures were performed either by or under the supervision of a single surgeon in a tertiary vascular unit serving a predominantly deprived population. Demographic and procedure-specific data were collected preoperatively and entered into a dedicated database. For the purposes of this study, anemia was determined by preoperative Hb values below the normal reference range of our hematology laboratory (<14 g/dL and <12 g/dL in men and women, respectively).

The primary end points were MACE and all-cause mortality at 30 days or during the patients’ hospital stay (whichever the longest). MACE was defined as one or more of the following: myocardial infarction (typical chest pain and/or ischemic ST segment changes on electrocardiography with a significant troponin T or I rise [>14 ng/L and >.1 ng/L, respectively]), coronary revascularization, sudden death, and left ventricular failure (independent clinical diagnosis and/or pulmonary congestion on chest radiography requiring acute treatment with diuretics, nitrates, or inotropes). 11 Except for selected patients, troponin assays were performed only when there was clinical suspicion of myocardial ischemia.

In order to identify preoperative predictors of outcome, specific variables were initially tested by univariate analysis. Potential associations with MACE and death on univariate tests were then entered into a multivariate model to identify independent associations. The variables tested were selected a priori. For MACE, these were the Eagle criteria (age, coronary disease, nondiet-controlled diabetes, Q waves on electrocardiography, but not ventricular ectopics, since this feature was not routinely sought in our patients), 12 revised cardiac risk index variables (coronary disease, congestive cardiac failure, cerebrovascular disease, diabetes on insulin, preoperative creatinine > 177 μmol/L, high-risk surgery—in this cohort, defined as any operation involving the abdominal aorta), 13 unplanned surgery (defined as any surgery performed during an unplanned admission), use of antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy, use of statins, 14 and use of β-blockers. 15 Age was categorized as > or ≤80 (instead of >70, as in the Eagle criteria), since this cutoff was previously found to be relevant in our patients. 16 For death, we added American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score, 17 sex, 18 and respiratory disease 19 to the above-mentioned variables.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Continuous variables were described with mean and standard deviation (SD) if normally distributed and median and quartiles (interquartile range [IQR]) if skewed. Comparisons between the groups were made using the unpaired t test and the Mann-Whitney U test, respectively. Categorical variables were compared with the chi-square test, with a continuity correction for 2 × 2 tables or with the Fisher exact test when cell numbers were low. Variables potentially associated with the outcome measures on univariate tests (P ≤ .1) were entered into a logistic regression model to establish whether preoperative Hb maintained an independent association with the outcome measures. For the purposes of this analysis, Hb was used as a continuous variable. All the analyses were performed on dedicated statistical software (PASW 18, Chicago, Illinois).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 360 patients (238 men) with a mean age (SD) of 69 (10.7) years were eligible for the analysis. Their physical status was typical of a population undergoing arterial surgery (Tables 1 and 2). Tissue loss was the commonest indication for surgery (Table 3) and 39.2% (n = 141) had undergone some form of vascular surgical intervention prior to their surgery. Most operations were infrainguinal reconstructions (262); 39 were extra-anatomical bypasses, 57 were suprainguinal reconstructions, and 2 combined supra and infrainguinal reconstructions. Autologous vein was the bypass conduit in 51.3% (n = 179) of the patients, with prosthetic (43.8%, n = 153), composite (4.5%, n = 16), and arterial homograft (0.3%, n = 1) also being used. In 11 patients, no conduit was used, as only an endarterectomy was performed.

sec.p: In all, 147 patients (40.8%) had a postoperative complication, the details of which are given in Table 4. In all, 26 (7%) had a postoperative MACE and 18 (5%) died.

fn.p: Abbreviation: MACE, major adverse cardiac events.

sec.p: The mean (SD) preoperative Hb was 13.0 (2.12) g/dL. Some 193 patients (53.6%) were anemic according to our definitions of whom 4.2% (n = 15) required intraoperative transfusion. MACE was common in patients with anemia (21 of 193 vs 5 of 167, P = .007) as was postoperative death (16/193 vs 2/167, P = .005). Figure 1 shows the incidence of MACE (A) and death (B) stratified by preoperative Hb concentration; Hb was significantly lower in patients who had a MACE, at a median (IQR) 11.1 (10.4-12.8) g/dL in comparison to uncomplicated cases, 13.3 (11.8-14.5) g/dL (P < .001). On univariate analysis, age, cerebrovascular disease, coronary disease, renal impairment (creatinine > 177 mol/L), left ventricular failure, and the use of β-blockers were also associated with MACE (Table 5). Preoperative Hb was also significantly lower in patients who died at a median (IQR) of 11.3 (9.4-13.2) g/dL in comparison to survivors, 13.2 (11.7-14.5) g/dL (P < .001). Other possible associations on univariate analysis were age, renal impairment, unplanned surgery, and ASA grade (Table 5).

sec.p: Multivariate analysis showed that, after correction for potential confounding variables, low Hb maintained an independent association with MACE (odds ratio [OR] for each 1 g/dL drop below the mean = 1.4 [1.13-1.7]; P = .002) and death (OR for each 1 g/dL drop below the mean = 1.5; 95% confidence interval [CI; 1.14-1.86]; P = .002). Age >80 years (OR = 3; 95% CI [1.2-7.5]; P = .025), renal impairment (OR = 3.2; 95% CI [.99-10.2]; P = .053), coronary disease (OR = 3.6; 95% CI [1.5-8.7]; P = .005) were also independently associated with MACE, while unplanned surgery (OR = 4.5; 95% CI [1.2-16.9]; P = .025) was associated with postoperative death.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We showed that preoperative anemia predicts MACE and death after peripheral arterial surgery even after adjustment for individual patients’ comorbid conditions. These results are in keeping with the previous publications on patients undergoing cardiac, orthopedic, and gastrointestinal surgery. 1–5

Anemia is a risk factor for MACE and, potentially, perioperative mortality because it reduces physiologic compensatory capacity in patients with low cardiac reserve and compounds compromised oxygen delivery in individuals with coronary artery disease. 20 Indeed in this particular cohort of patients, coronary disease is a frequent finding with reported prevalence ranging from 14% to 90%. 9 Moreover, up to 71% of patients with PAD have been found to have subclinical coronary disease. 21–22 In addition, anemia may be caused by malnutrition, iron deficiency, bone marrow depression, and increased circulating levels of proinflammatory cytokines as well as being a common and interrelated finding in patients with diabetes 23 and renal dysfunction. 24 It is therefore difficult to ascertain whether anemia is a causative factor for the clinical outcomes reported in this study or simply a reflection of the physiological conditions of this cohort of patients and perhaps the burden of atherosclerotic disease.

Establishing the existence of a causal relationship between anemia and adverse clinical outcome is important, since this knowledge will guide the most effective therapy for preoperative anemia. Addressing anemia effectively assumes a causal link between anemia and poor outcome. However, there is little evidence for the use of intravenous iron in this setting, 25 and while there is more encouraging evidence for the use of erythropoietin, 26 its use can also result in a higher incidence of thrombotic events 27 and as such may not be beneficial to patients undergoing vascular procedure for PAS. Blood transfusion is another option for correcting preoperative anemia but has its attendant risks. 28–30 Although this risk is minimal with modern processing techniques, it often outweighs the potential benefit of blood transfusion in normovolemic surgical patients. 31 Some studies have shown a trend toward lower mortality and morbidity rates when a lower threshold for transfusion is used 32 ; however, no benefit has been shown in patients with preexisting coronary disease. 33,34

A recent study has shown that anemia (in particular iron deficiency) is more prevalent in patients with critical ischemia than those with intermittent claudication 35 and perhaps supports the notion that preoperative anemia is a marker of poor physiological conditions. Furthermore patients with critical ischemia also have chronic inflammation and gangrene and are therefore more prone to anemia of chronic disease. 36 This may in part explain the association between unplanned surgery and increased mortality demonstrated in this study, since this group of patients would be expected to have more severe PAD.

Although it is possible to investigate and address iron-deficiency anemia preoperatively, it should be noted that many of our patients required urgent intervention, therefore, the time available for assessment and correction of anemia may have been limited. In such instances awareness of preoperative anemia may be more useful as a risk stratification tool and perhaps guide the choice of intervention in cases of equipoise between conventional surgery and less invasive endovascular therapies.

This study cannot determine whether a causal link exists between anemia and adverse clinical outcome; therefore, further studies are necessary. Furthermore, investigation and correction of anemia may be impossible or impractical for many patients and may not improve outcome if low Hb is simply a marker of poor physiological status. As such, we suggest that in potential candidates for PAD surgery the presence of anemia should be considered a marker of risk in the preoperative decision-making process and during patients’ counseling/consent. In particular cases, it may add weight to a decision to offer conservative or percutaneous treatment instead of surgery.
